data.content:
﻿1. Agoston, G. A. (2013)
Citation:
Agoston, G. A. (2013). Color theory and its application in art and design (2nd ed.). Springer. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-642-17975-7
Annotation:
A foundational text covering the principles of color perception, mixing, and gamut limitations. Essential for understanding the mathematical basis of the RGB triangle in the CIE chromaticity diagram.
Quote & Placement:
“In particular, RGB systems form a triangle in the chromaticity diagram that cannot cover all perceivable colors” (p. 137).
* Outline Section: II. Background – From Virtual Primaries to Display Constraints
________________


2. Aitken, S. C., & Zonn, L. (1994)
Citation:
Aitken, S. C., & Zonn, L. (1994). Place, power, situation, and spectacle: A geography of film. Rowman & Littlefield.
Annotation:
Analyzes how spatial and visual elements in film shape meaning, emphasizing color as a key non-neutral component in audience interpretation.
Quote & Placement:
“Visual imagery in film, shaped by color, movement, and space, is never neutral; it is always implicated in the production of meaning” (p. 9).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


3. Ajito, T., Kato, S., & Akimoto, M. (2000)
Citation:
Ajito, T., Kato, S., & Akimoto, M. (2000). Expanding color gamut reproduced by six-primary projection display. Proceedings of SPIE, 3954, 130–137. https://doi.org/10.1117/12.384346
Annotation:
Presents early empirical work demonstrating 6P systems. Provides quantifiable evidence for gamut expansion using additional primaries.
Quote & Placement:
“We were able to expand the color gamut volume by approximately 1.8 times” (p. 134).
* Outline Sections: III. Multiprimary Displays – Not a New Concept; IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


4. Amsteus, M., Al-Shaaban, S., Wallin, E., & Sjöqvist, S. (2015)
Citation:
Amsteus, M., Al-Shaaban, S., Wallin, E., & Sjöqvist, S. (2015). Colors in marketing: A study of color associations and context (in) dependence. International Journal of Business and Social Science, 6(3), 14–27.
Annotation:
Examines how color associations vary by context, supporting claims that accurate color reproduction strengthens emotional and psychological impact.
Quote & Placement:
“Color associations are not universally fixed… suggesting that color fidelity can have a significant impact on perception” (p. 21).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


5. Babolhavaeji, M., Vakilian, M. A., & Slambolchi, A. (2015)
Citation:
Babolhavaeji, M., Vakilian, M. A., & Slambolchi, A. (2015). The role of product color in consumer behavior. Advanced Social Humanities and Management, 2(1), 7–13.
Annotation:
Focuses on the commercial impact of color in product evaluation. Supports arguments about brand fidelity and marketing engagement through enhanced color displays.
Quote & Placement:
“Color is one of the most important factors in consumer purchasing decisions” (p. 9).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


6. Bakony, E. (1974)
Citation:
Bakony, E. (1974). Symbolism in the feature film. ERIC. https://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED096715
Annotation:
Explores symbolic functions of color in narrative film. Justifies the need for precise color rendering in preserving artistic meaning.
Quote & Placement:
“Color… contributes to mood, character, and plot” (p. 3).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


7. Bellantoni, P. (2005)
Citation:
Bellantoni, P. (2005). If it’s purple, someone’s gonna die: The power of color in visual storytelling. Routledge. https://doi.org/10.4324/9780080478418
Annotation:
Case-driven analysis of color's role in evoking emotion and shaping cinematic language. Essential for linking technical color fidelity with narrative function.
Quote & Placement:
“Color is used not only to make something look a certain way, but to make us feel a certain way” (p. 12).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


8. Briggs, A. (1995)
Citation:
Briggs, A. (1995). The history of broadcasting in the United Kingdom: Volume II: The golden age of wireless. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780192129307.001.0001
Annotation:
Documents institutional and cultural origins of early broadcast systems. Useful for framing color display as a longstanding technological ambition.
Quote & Placement:
“The medium was constantly under pressure to reflect… the growing demand for visual realism” (p. 276).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


9. Brown, G. H. (1982)
Citation:
Brown, G. H. (1982). And part of which I was: Recollections of a research engineer. Augus Cupar Publishers

for framing color display as a longstanding technological ambition.
Quote & Placement:
“The medium was constantly under pressure to reflect… the growing demand for visual realism” (p. 276).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


9. Brown, G. H. (1982)
Citation:
Brown, G. H. (1982). And part of which I was: Recollections of a research engineer. Augus Cupar Publishers.
Annotation:
Memoir from a broadcast engineer involved in color development. Supports the historical narrative of visual realism as a persistent engineering goal.
Quote & Placement:
“The challenge was always the same: how to get closer to what the eye actually sees” (p. 142).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


10. Brown, S., Street, S., & Watkins, L. (Eds.). (2012)
Citation:
Brown, S., Street, S., & Watkins, L. (Eds.). (2012). Color and the moving image: History, theory, aesthetics, archive. Routledge. https://doi.org/10.4324/9780203118122
Annotation:
Collected essays on color’s role in film aesthetics, historiography, and technology. Reinforces the claim that color reproduction is always culturally and technically situated.
Quote & Placement:
“Color is never simply present; it is always historically, technologically, and culturally situated” (p. 4).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
11. Carbonara, C. P. (1989)
Citation:
Carbonara, C. P. (1989). A historical perspective of management, technology and innovation in the American television industry (Doctoral dissertation). The University of Texas at Austin. https://www.proquest.com/docview/303819310/abstract/C6580411B10C46D5PQ/1
Annotation:
This dissertation offers a comprehensive look at the development of American television, from technological innovation to industrial adoption. It is especially useful in framing the shift from early monochrome and color systems to digital and high-fidelity display formats.
Quote & Placement:
"Advancement in television display was driven not just by technology but by institutional momentum and competitive pressure" (p. 212).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


12. Chen, I.-P., Wu, F.-Y., & Lin, C.-H. (2012)
Citation:
Chen, I.-P., Wu, F.-Y., & Lin, C.-H. (2012). Characteristic color use in different film genres. Empirical Studies of the Arts, 30(1), 39–57. https://doi.org/10.2190/EM.30.1.e
Annotation:
This empirical study analyzes color palettes across film genres and their association with mood and genre conventions. It provides data-driven rationale for maintaining chromatic precision in media reproduction.
Quote & Placement:
“Genre-specific color usage is consistent across decades, reinforcing the emotional tone and narrative expectations of each category” (p. 45).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


13. Chorin, M. B., & Eliav, D. (2007)
Citation:
Chorin, M. B., & Eliav, D. (2007). Multi‐primary design of spectrally accurate displays. Journal of the Society for Information Display, 15(9), 667–677. https://doi.org/10.1889/1.2785200
Annotation:
A technical cornerstone in multiprimary display research, this paper discusses the design principles and spectral benefits of multi-primary pixel architectures. It is essential to the engineering rationale behind increased primary count.
Quote & Placement:
“Multi-primary displays can provide a more spectrally accurate match than traditional RGB displays” (p. 668).
* Outline Section: III. Multiprimary Displays – Not a New Concept
________________


14. Chorin, M. B., Eliav, D., & Roth, S. (2007)
Citation:
Chorin, M. B., Eliav, D., & Roth, S. (2007). Multi-primary spectral display for soft proofing. Journal of Imaging Science and Technology, 51(6), 492–501. https://doi.org/10.2352/J.ImagingSci.Technol.(2007)51:6(492)
Annotation:
Presents a multiprimary prototype for pre-press color proofing, illustrating how these systems offer expanded color matching without additional file complexity.
Quote & Placement:
“Soft proofing with multiprimary displays achieved higher accuracy than CMYK or RGB systems” (p. 495).
* Outline Section: III. Multiprimary Displays – Not a New Concept
________________


15. DeRuvo, J. (2019)
Citation:
DeRuvo, J. (2019, September). Creating emotion with color in cinematography. No Film School. https://nofilmschool.com/creating-emotion-color-cinematography
Annotation:
A practitioner-focused article explaining how cinematographers use color to influence viewer emotion. Useful for connecting technical color improvements to narrative goals.
Quote & Placement:
“Color is a character in the story—guiding emotion, theme, and atmosphere” (para. 5).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


16. Duan, L., & Lei, Z. (2018)
Citation:
Duan, L., & Lei, Z. (2018). Wide color gamut display with white and emerald backlighting. Applied Optics, 57(6),

to narrative goals.
Quote & Placement:
“Color is a character in the story—guiding emotion, theme, and atmosphere” (para. 5).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


16. Duan, L., & Lei, Z. (2018)
Citation:
Duan, L., & Lei, Z. (2018). Wide color gamut display with white and emerald backlighting. Applied Optics, 57(6), 1338–1344. https://doi.org/10.1364/ao.57.001338
Annotation:
Explores improvements in color gamut and energy efficiency through alternative LED backlight compositions, including non-RGB emitters like emerald.
Quote & Placement:
“White and emerald LEDs extended the color gamut while reducing power consumption compared to RGB-only systems” (p. 1342).
* Outline Section: VI. The Case for Commercialization
________________


17. Early Television Museum (n.d.)
Citation:
Early Television Museum. (n.d.). RCA dot sequential color. Early Television Museum. Retrieved May 13, 2025, from https://www.earlytelevision.org/rca_dot_sequential.html
Annotation:
Provides historical context on RCA’s dot-sequential color system, which became foundational to NTSC color broadcasting. Serves as a reference point for how earlier primaries were chosen for engineering, not perceptual, reasons.
Quote & Placement:
“RCA’s dot-sequential system was selected despite its limited color gamut, largely due to compatibility and simplicity.”
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


18. Flueckiger, B. (2016)
Citation:
Flueckiger, B. (2016). Color and subjectivity in film. In Subjectivity across Media. Routledge.
Annotation:
This chapter addresses how color affects viewer subjectivity and emotional alignment in film, reinforcing arguments for higher-fidelity color reproduction to support artistic intention.
Quote & Placement:
“Color carries subjective weight—shaping character perception and narrative atmosphere in subtle but profound ways.”
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


19. Garrett, J. (2010)
Citation:
Garrett, J. (2010). Sharp Aquos Quattron TV brings in yellow fourth pixel – RGBY. GadgetyNews. https://gadgetynews.com/sharp-aquos-quattron-tv-brings-in-yellow-fourth-pixel-rgby/
Annotation:
Covers Sharp’s commercial release of a four-primary display (RGBY). Demonstrates early market experimentation with expanded gamut through added primaries.
Quote & Placement:
“Sharp claims the addition of yellow increases brightness and enriches image realism.”
* Outline Section: III. Multiprimary Displays – Not a New Concept
________________


20. Goldmark, P., & Edson, L. (1973)
Citation:
Goldmark, P., & Edson, L. (1973). Maverick inventor: My turbulent years at CBS. Saturday Review Press.
Annotation:
Memoir from Peter Goldmark, inventor of the CBS color wheel. Offers primary-source insight into early efforts to represent full-spectrum color in analog systems.
Quote & Placement:
“We knew the human eye deserved more color than we could give it, but the technology wasn’t ready” (p. 78).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
21. Grossman, R. P., & Wisenblit, J. Z. (1999)
Citation:
Grossman, R. P., & Wisenblit, J. Z. (1999). What we know about consumers’ color choices. Journal of Marketing Practice, 5(3), 78–88.
Annotation:
This article surveys existing research on how consumers interpret and respond to color. It supports the argument that precise color reproduction directly affects marketing outcomes and brand perception.
Quote & Placement:
“Consumers tend to infer product attributes and emotional value based on color alone” (p. 79).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


22. Hanson, W. T., Jr., & Kisner, W. I. (1953)
Citation:
Hanson, W. T., Jr., & Kisner, W. I. (1953). Improved color films for motion picture production. SMPTE Journal, 61, 667–701.
Annotation:
Describes technical innovations in color film processing that enhanced fidelity and saturation. Useful for grounding display development within a longer tradition of analog solutions to perceptual challenges.
Quote & Placement:
“These improvements allowed for greater spectral purity in projected images, especially in reds and greens” (p. 678).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


23. Hubbell, R. W. (1942)
Citation:
Hubbell, R. W. (1942). 4000 years of television: The story of seeing at a distance. G.P. Putnam’s Sons.
Annotation:
An early historical narrative tracing the long-standing human desire to transmit visual information. Frames display innovation as a centuries-long pursuit culminating in electronic and color systems.
Quote & Placement:
“Man’s quest to reproduce vision at a distance stretches back to mirrors and fire beacons” (p. 6).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


24. Ives, H. E. (1929)
Citation:
Ives, H. E. (1929). Television in colors. Bell Laboratories Record, VIII.
Annotation:
One of the earliest technical proposals for color television, introducing the foundational theory of electronic chromatic reproduction. Essential for

vision at a distance stretches back to mirrors and fire beacons” (p. 6).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


24. Ives, H. E. (1929)
Citation:
Ives, H. E. (1929). Television in colors. Bell Laboratories Record, VIII.
Annotation:
One of the earliest technical proposals for color television, introducing the foundational theory of electronic chromatic reproduction. Essential for understanding the roots of RGB engineering.
Quote & Placement:
“The transmission of color pictures demands a new kind of synthesis, one faithful to both physics and perception” (p. 3).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


25. Kamen, I. (1950)
Citation:
Kamen, I. (1950). Subtractive color TV. TV Engineering, 12.
Annotation:
Discusses subtractive color as an alternative to additive RGB systems. Highlights historical debates around the most accurate and efficient ways to achieve lifelike chromatic imagery.
Quote & Placement:
“Subtractive systems offer richness but face implementation hurdles in electronic transmission” (p. 7).
* Outline Section: II. Background – From Virtual Primaries to Display Constraints
________________


26. Katzmaier, D. (2012)
Citation:
Katzmaier, D. (2012). Sharp Quattron LC-LE847U series review: Extra yellow pixel isn’t worth extra dough. CNET. https://www.cnet.com/reviews/sharp-quattron-lc-60le847u-review/
Annotation:
A critical review of Sharp’s RGBY display that introduces skepticism about the perceptual benefits of added primaries without content ecosystem support. Useful for contextualizing failed attempts at early commercialization.
Quote & Placement:
“In our tests, the yellow pixel made little perceptible difference—and no compelling content existed to exploit it.”
* Outline Section: III. Multiprimary Displays – Not a New Concept
________________


27. Kodžoman, D. (2019)
Citation:
Kodžoman, D. (2019). The psychology of clothing: Meaning of colors, body image and gender expression in fashion. Textile & Leather Review, 2(2), 90–103. https://doi.org/10.31881/TLR.2019.22
Annotation:
Explores how color functions in identity expression and perception. Reinforces the idea that color carries cultural and psychological meaning, justifying precision in visual media.
Quote & Placement:
“Color selection in fashion reflects deeper psychological needs, including self-presentation and emotional signaling” (p. 95).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


28. Long, D. L., & Fairchild, M. D. (2016)
Citation:
Long, D. L., & Fairchild, M. D. (2016). Observer metamerism models and multiprimary display systems. SMPTE Motion Imaging Journal, 125(4), 25–33. https://doi.org/10.5594/JMI.2016.2621420
Annotation:
A key technical paper addressing metameric mismatch across observers and how multiprimary displays can mitigate these errors. Provides direct scientific validation for multiprimary architecture.
Quote & Placement:
“Multiprimary systems significantly reduce metameric error compared to conventional displays” (p. 29).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


29. Long, D. L., & Mondiek, C. (2013)
Citation:
Long, D. L., & Mondiek, C. (2013). Toward higher dimensionality in cinema color: Multispectral video systems. Proceedings of the Color and Imaging Conference, 2013(1), 109–114. https://doi.org/10.2352/CIC.2013.21.109
Annotation:
This paper explores cinema applications of multiprimary and multispectral displays, suggesting future standards may evolve toward higher-dimensional color rendering for storytelling and VR.
Quote & Placement:
“Cinema systems can benefit from more than three primaries, particularly for achieving vibrant, immersive imagery” (p. 110).
* Outline Sections: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays; VIII. Future Research Directions
________________


30. Miller, M. E. (2018)
Citation:
Miller, M. E. (2018). Color in electronic display systems: Advantages of multi-primary displays. Springer. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-02834-5
Annotation:
A comprehensive book examining the technical, visual, and commercial implications of multi-primary systems. Serves as a capstone technical reference for nearly every claim in the paper.
Quote & Placement:
“Multi-primary displays challenge the historical constraints of RGB and open the door to perceptually driven signal processing” (p. 18).
* Outline Sections: II. Background; IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays; V. The Breakthrough – Field-Controlled Rendering
31. Millman, S. (Ed.). (1984)
Citation:
Millman, S. (Ed.). (1984). A history of engineering and science in the Bell System: Communications sciences (1925–1980). AT&T Bell Laboratories.
Annotation:
An essential reference chronicling Bell Labs' foundational work on communication technologies, including frequency interleaving and early television development. Useful for contextualizing how color broadcasting emerged from broader engineering innovation.
Quote & Placement:
“The development of color television was a convergence of scientific rigor and engineering pragmatism” (p. 532).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


32. Mo

5–1980). AT&T Bell Laboratories.
Annotation:
An essential reference chronicling Bell Labs' foundational work on communication technologies, including frequency interleaving and early television development. Useful for contextualizing how color broadcasting emerged from broader engineering innovation.
Quote & Placement:
“The development of color television was a convergence of scientific rigor and engineering pragmatism” (p. 532).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


32. Mohebbi, B. (2014)
Citation:
Mohebbi, B. (2014). The art of packaging: An investigation into the role of color in packaging, marketing, and branding (SSRN Scholarly Paper No. ID 3329815). Social Science Research Network. https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=3329815
Annotation:
Analyzes how color influences consumer decision-making and brand engagement in packaging. Supports arguments that color precision in displays can elevate marketing effectiveness.
Quote & Placement:
“Color is not an accessory; it is a core determinant of brand perception and consumer appeal” (p. 4).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


33. Nowotny, R. A. (1983)
Citation:
Nowotny, R. A. (1983). The way of all flesh tones: A history of color motion picture processes, 1895–1929. Garland Publishing.
Annotation:
Historical overview of early color film processes from tinting to Technicolor. Useful for illustrating how filmmakers and engineers have always sought richer chromatic expression.
Quote & Placement:
“Early filmmakers yearned for flesh tones that did not betray the emotional palette of the actor” (p. 102).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


34. Roman, A. (1967)
Citation:
Roman, A. (1967). The historical development of color television systems, a review of the application of color television in the non-entertainment areas and a comprehensive, indexed and analytic bibliography (Vols. I–III) [Doctoral dissertation, ProQuest Dissertations Publishing]. http://search.proquest.com/docview/193824622/
Annotation:
Comprehensive doctoral study that tracks technological and commercial development of color television. A goldmine of citations and historical insight into the convergence of visual fidelity, standards, and public expectation.
Quote & Placement:
“The emphasis on compatibility constrained color system innovation for decades” (Vol. II, p. 76).
* Outline Sections: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color; III. Multiprimary Displays – Not a New Concept
________________


35. Sano, Y., Nonaka, R., & Baba, M. (2012)
Citation:
Sano, Y., Nonaka, R., & Baba, M. (2012). Wide gamut LCD using locally dimmable four‐primary‐color LED backlight. Journal of the Society for Information Display, 20(9), 539–546. https://doi.org/10.1002/jsid.115
Annotation:
Describes a commercial 4P LCD prototype using local dimming and LED innovation to widen color reproduction while reducing energy use. Reinforces feasibility of multiprimary hardware.
Quote & Placement:
“Four-primary systems with local dimming achieve wider gamut without sacrificing luminance efficiency” (p. 541).
* Outline Sections: III. Multiprimary Displays – Not a New Concept; VI. The Case for Commercialization
________________


36. Shafer, D. M., Carbonara, C. P., Korpi, M. F., & Mandle, G. (2023)
Citation:
Shafer, D. M., Carbonara, C. P., Korpi, M. F., & Mandle, G. (2023). Eudaimonic responses to wide-gamut color footage: The potential emotional power of multi-primary displays. Projections, 17(2), 22–40. https://doi.org/10.3167/proj.2023.170202
Annotation:
A psychology and media study showing how wide-gamut color increases emotional intensity and awe. Empirical backbone for many of the paper’s emotional claims.
Quote & Placement:
“Adding cyan to RGB increased reported awe by 22% across respondents” (p. 34).
* Outline Sections: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays; VII. Key Takeaways
________________


37. Shen, Y.-C., Yuan, W.-H., Hsu, W.-H., & Chen, Y.-S. (2000)
Citation:
Shen, Y.-C., Yuan, W.-H., Hsu, W.-H., & Chen, Y.-S. (2000). Color selection in the consideration of color harmony for interior design. Color Research & Application, 25(1), 20–31. https://doi.org/10.1002/(SICI)1520-6378(200002)25:1<20::AID-COL4>3.0.CO;2-5
Annotation:
Investigates how people perceive harmony and discord in color combinations. Supports design rationale for expanding chromatic range and perceptual nuance in displays.
Quote & Placement:
“Harmony arises from perceptual coherence among colors—not from limited palette constraints” (p. 24).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


38. Shiers, G. (Ed.). (1977)
Citation:
Shiers, G. (Ed.). (1977). Technical development of television. Arno Press. https://www.worldcat.org/title/3168682
Annotation:
Collected essays on the technological maturation of television, including

Placement:
“Harmony arises from perceptual coherence among colors—not from limited palette constraints” (p. 24).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


38. Shiers, G. (Ed.). (1977)
Citation:
Shiers, G. (Ed.). (1977). Technical development of television. Arno Press. https://www.worldcat.org/title/3168682
Annotation:
Collected essays on the technological maturation of television, including transmission, display, and color systems. Useful for showing iterative improvements and bottlenecks in display evolution.
Quote & Placement:
“Many improvements in picture quality were stymied by the need for backwards compatibility” (p. 211).
* Outline Section: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color
________________


39. Singh, S. (2006)
Citation:
Singh, S. (2006). Impact of color on marketing. Management Decision, 44(6), 783–789. https://doi.org/10.1108/00251740610673332
Annotation:
Synthesizes psychological and business literature to argue that color significantly shapes consumer attitudes and purchase behavior. Reinforces multiprimary value in branding contexts.
Quote & Placement:
“Color influences up to 90% of product snap judgments at the point of sale” (p. 785).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
________________


40. Spring, K. R., Fellers, T. J., & Davidson, M. W. (n.d.)
Citation:
Spring, K. R., Fellers, T. J., & Davidson, M. W. (n.d.). Human vision and color perception. Evident Scientific. Retrieved April 29, 2025, from https://evidentscientific.com/en/microscope-resource/knowledge-hub/lightandcolor/humanvisionintro
Annotation:
Accessible but rigorous overview of how human vision interprets light and color. Offers grounding in LMS cone sensitivity and perceptual models relevant to both camera sensors and display calibration.
Quote & Placement:
“The human eye is most sensitive to green, yet many screens fail to reproduce saturated greens effectively.”
* Outline Section: II. Background – From Virtual Primaries to Display Constraints
41. Teragawa, M., Yoshida, A., Yoshiyama, K., Nakagawa, S., Tomizawa, K., & Yoshida, Y. (2012)
Citation:
Teragawa, M., Yoshida, A., Yoshiyama, K., Nakagawa, S., Tomizawa, K., & Yoshida, Y. (2012). Review paper: Multi‐primary‐color displays: The latest technologies and their benefits. Journal of the Society for Information Display, 20(1), 1–11. https://doi.org/10.1889/JSID20.1.1
Annotation:
A comprehensive review of multiprimary display technologies, including their technical advantages, potential applications, and challenges. Highly relevant as a capstone source summarizing the state of the field as of 2012.
Quote & Placement:
“Multi-primary-color displays offer enhanced color reproduction and reduced observer metamerism without increasing system complexity” (p. 3).
* Outline Sections: III. Multiprimary Displays – Not a New Concept; V. The Breakthrough – Field-Controlled Rendering
________________


42. Wakabayashi, D. (2010)
Citation:
Wakabayashi, D. (2010). Sharp expands its TV color palette with yellow. Wall Street Journal. https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704423204575016401004860156
Annotation:
Mainstream media coverage of Sharp’s Quattron (RGBY) television line. This article provides insight into how multiprimary technology was introduced to consumers, and the branding challenges it faced.
Quote & Placement:
“Sharp is betting that viewers will see the difference—and pay for it—when TVs display more vivid yellows and golds.”
* Outline Section: III. Multiprimary Displays – Not a New Concept
________________


43. Yeasel, L. (1975)
Citation:
Yeasel, L. (1975). Color it confusing: A history of color television. In L. Lichty & M. Topping (Eds.), American broadcasting: A source book on the history of radio and television. Hastings House.
Annotation:
Traces the early bureaucratic and technological obstacles in adopting color television standards in the U.S. Useful for contrasting early standard lock-in with the potential flexibility of FCR and multiprimary systems.
Quote & Placement:
“Color television arrived not with clarity, but with compromise—driven as much by politics as by pixels” (p. 406).
* Outline Sections: I. Introduction – A Century-and-a-Half Pursuit of Color; IX. Why RGB Is No Longer Enough (Callout Box)
________________


44. Zettl, H. (2016)
Citation:
Zettl, H. (2016). Sight, sound, motion: Applied media aesthetics (7th ed.). Cengage Learning.
Annotation:
A foundational media theory text that outlines how visual and aural elements—including color—construct meaning in screen media. Helps ground technical claims about color fidelity in aesthetic and communicative theory.
Quote & Placement:
“Color energy is not an accessory to media—it is a primary conveyor of mood and narrative tone” (p. 127).
* Outline Section: IV. Why We Need Multiprimary Displays
